Definition: The chronology number as seen on Figure 3 and  Extended Data Figures 6-7. Each number corresponds to a unique site/species combo.
The geographical location that the cores were collected from to create the chronology.
The species used to create the chronology
The porosity of the species used to generate the chronology. Either ring-porous (RP) or diffuse-porous (DP).

Database in which data are archived (DEN= The DendroEcological Network; ITRDB= International Tree-Ring Data Bank; HF = Harvard Forest Data Archive). Note that all chronologies are available in the GitHub (https://github.com/EcoClimLab/growth_phenology).
Accession code. For DEN database, this is the project ID.
URL of archived data (corresponding to Archive Location).
Data DOI. May refer to a different archive location than the database listed in previous fields.
The latitude of the location where the cores used to generate the chronology were collected.
The longitude of the location where the cores used to generate the chronology were collected.
The average minimum temperature in April
The average maximum temperature in April
The correlation value between January maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between January maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The correlation value between February maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between February maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The correlation value between March maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between March maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The correlation value between April maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between April maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The correlation value between May maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between May maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The correlation value between June maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between June maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The correlation value between July maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between July maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The correlation value between August maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. Represented by color in Figure 3.
The significance of the correlation value between August maximum temperature and yearly ring-width across all study years. 0.05 if 95%, or 0.002 if 99.8%, confidence interval did not include 0.
The slope of the April factor in the linear model run to determine the interacting effect between spring and summer temperatures on yearly ring-widths
The p-value of the April factor in the linear model run to determine the interacting effect between spring and summer temperatures on yearly ring-widths
The slope of the June-July factor in the linear model run to determine the interacting effect between spring and summer temperatures on yearly ring-widths
The p-value of the June-July factor in the linear model run to determine the interacting effect between spring and summer temperatures on yearly ring-widths
